comment:
Nose: nail polish remover, with slight vanillas.

Palette: buttery and oily at first. Oak in the middle and finishes with some spice.
Very small batch, very sweet and salty

All of the Bourbon goodness without the sticky Bourbon cloy.

Nose: 
Gentle with a wide layer of spice, coffee and pepper.
Dried dates, apricots and juicy cherries. 
Light vanilla, with a luscious cream. 
Eucalyptus? Mint? Fresh cut herbs?

Palate:
So fresh, yet dry, spicy and woody.
Vanilla remains light, filling in the gaps instead of layering on a thick layer.
Sweetness and cream round off all of the baking spices, and eucalyptus.

Finish:
The cream fades into a woody, spicy and dry finish.
Complex and hidden sweetness under the leather
Buttery/nutty, with just the right amount of herbal spice/mint.  Nice oily mouthfeel. A good balanced combo of smooth and spicy.  I really like this one.
Lighter in flavor. Sweeter. Would prefer something darker with more oak. Very smooth on the rocks.

Aroma: Fruit

Taste: Smooth and fruity

Aftertaste: No bite, just smooth.
A little harsher on the finish than I expected.
Light nose,red dry wine, salted butter popcorn, caramel.  Thinking cracker jacks.  Overall a nice pour but wouldn’t buy a bottle
A Little weak for my taste.
Very inviting and fruity nose. Good with one cube. Spicy burn to finish. Nice bourbon!

Has a great kick, little bit fruity taste, with a good char finish. Definitely a drink you want to enjoy with great friends. 

If you have drank the Jeffersons Small Batch before.. Jeffersons Reserve is much better in taste. I'd recommend a couple ice cubes to dilute it a bit but everyone is different. I enjoy Jeffersons Reserve on the rocks.
Just didn't notice any flavor, was too melow
Underwhelming to me, not a lot of flavor for the price.
I like this more every time I drink it. Really smooth finish, but would ultimately love to find it a little cheaper .
This is one of the better bourbons I have had. The Aged at Sea version is better but much more expensive.
Smooth and very flavorful.  Great drinker
Not a fan.  A little better than the Ocean
Disappointing, heat is overwhelming everything, a bit of ice made it tolerable.
Warm after taste. Vanilla and caramel

I hope I just got a bad bottle and it isn't all just as forgettable on the nose as well as the tongue as this is. Absolutely zero nose. To the point I struggle just to smell alcohol. Nothing but caramel on the taste. Worst bourbon I've ever tasted. Very unfortunate at $50!

Neat -oak earth not hot
Water and ice-consistent with neat
Very nice. One of my favorite house bourbons to have around.

It's a good bourbon with pleasant flavors, and I do enjoy it. However, I can't seem to find anything very impressive about it at its price range. I got this on sale, but the original price was in the same range as some barrel proof or non-chill filtered types I'd rather buy.
I was having a hard time pinning down what I was tasting - then I read the tasting notes on here. Fruits, honeysuckle... unexpected!
Sweet, smooth, syrupy, nice oak finish
Very mild notes. Maybe brown sugar. Hard to find definite notes. Smooth. Oaky notes on the finish.
Slightly more spicy than regular Jefferson, very good & solid bourbon
A nice start, but an annoying bitter after-taste. Smooth, but ...
I like Jeffersons flavor profile. I get a little salty brine on the palate with their products. Whether it is oceans or not. This is good. Not sure it is a great value. But worth a try.
Vanilla and Brown sugar on the nose.   Crisp apple with spice on the palate.  Finish is smooth with spice.
Picked by la local party store.  Batch H-121 bottle 69.  I give this a 3.8 or 3.9.  Sweet on the front and spice on the finish.  Drank neat, fairly easy drinker.
Sweet & fruity nose. Softer/smooth taste with a herb & slightly spicy finish. Very different style and great to try
So smooth with plenty of Oak and Corn. Clean going down and a nice Smokey finish

This is my official deep dive into Jefferson’s. Feel free to skip ahead to the tasting, because there are going to be a bunch of these cheesy intros, all copy/paste.
~~~~~~~~~~
Concept:

I walk into a liquor store and see like a billion different Jefferson’s bottles, yet my knowledge of them is minimal. My perception is that I typically don’t care for their stuff, but somehow, before choosing to start this experiment, I already had six different Jefferson’s on my shelf. How did they invade my house?
~~~~~~~~~~
Methodology:

Step 1: Jefferson’s Very Small Batch. Patient 0. Where it all started? Never had it, so a damn good place to start. This one was bought specifically for this experiment.

Step 2:  Jefferson’s VSB vs Jefferson’s Reserve (Very Old Very Small Batch). I already had this one. How did this get in my house?

Step 3: Jefferson’s VSB vs Jefferson’s Ocean. Is it a gimmick? Again, how did this get in my house?

Step 4: Jefferson’s Ocean standard vs Jefferson’s Ocean wheated mash bill.  Repeat house question.

Step 5: Finished Jefferson’s. I got rum, Sauternes, and Prichard Hill. Let’s do this.

Step 6: Blind taste test with all 7. Hell, throw in Chef’s Collaboration. (Seriously, how?) So there’s 8. Can I pick them out based on steps 1-5? Are there any standout Jefferson’s expressions, or is it all marketing? The stakes are so low, the tension is palpable. 
~~~~~~~~~~
Disclaimer: 

Starting this, I don’t much care for Jefferson’s in general. There’s this weird gummy-bear-ness that I can’t shake. Hoping to find my Jefferson’s product by the time this is over.
~~~~~~~~~~
Jefferson’s Reserve, aka “Step 2”

Okay, so THERE’S the Jefferson’s I recall not liking. I knew it had to be there somewhere. On the nose, there’s some form of jelly. I usually say grape, but it’s more of a raspberry right now. There’s vanilla and oak too, but that jelly is dominant.

Body is back to grape jelly. It hits in full force. Midway through the body there’s a mustiness that creeps in. I’d have to call it a dust flavor. Don’t love it, but it’s familiar. I think I’ve had it before in some Elijah Craig variants. It fades away as the dram goes on. There’s a bit of fresh cedar too.

Finish is very mild in feel, with a peppery taste and a pleasant tongue burn. Bit of cedar carries through, but the pepper is the main star.

So this dram has that grape jelly flavor that I negatively associate with Jefferson’s, but it’s far more palatable than it was in other versions I’ve had previously, particularly the Sauternes finish. I don’t hate this drink, but I do find it very interesting that it’s not as good IMO as the cheaper basic option. It’s also unfortunate for me that so many of these little bastards on my shelf are variants of Jefferson’s Reserve. Assuming the blending is similar before the cask finish, I’m still hoping the cask finishes can tone down that jelly flavor.
Very nice and decent bourbon that nothing stood out like it a bourbon at this price should have

This is a wonderful flavorful bourbon which I just keep coming back to. It is not too complex but it has personality, smooth with enough of a kick for me. I normally pick it up for around $36 and find it good value. I have seen it on the shelf at some outlets closer to $50 which is very sobering. If you can find it under $40 give it a go.
